sections.title: Failed implant replacement in Shoreham-by-Sea
sections.body: If a dental implant has failed, become loose, or caused ongoing problems, a careful review can help determine the safest next steps. We start by understanding what happened because every case is different.

sections.title: A careful approach when things haven’t gone to plan
items: Time to listen and understand history
CBCT imaging to assess bone and implant position

sections.title: Why do dental implants fail?
sections.body: Common factors can include infection, bone loss, bite forces, smoking, systemic health, implant position, and maintenance issues. Every case is different, so we review your records and scans before recommending any change.

sections.title: Who is this assessment for?
items: Concerns about bone loss around an implant
Anyone unsure whether an implant can be saved or replaced
sections.honestQualifier: Not every implant can or should be replaced immediately — assessment comes first.

sections.title: Your pathway: review to next steps
Assessment tools that guide safer decisions
sections.body: Diagnostics and planning lead every recommendation — technology supports careful assessment rather than rushed treatment. Replacement isn’t always immediate, and the right tools help us map the safest sequence.

sections.title: Healing, risks, and realistic expectations
items: Why rushing replacement can reduce success
Healing periods may be needed between stages
Reassurance: a structured plan improves outcomes

faqs.question: Why did my implant fail?
faqs.answer: Causes vary — infection, bite forces, bone quality, smoking, systemic health, positioning, and maintenance can all play a role. We review your specific history and scans before advising next steps.

faqs.question: Can a failed implant be replaced?
faqs.answer: Sometimes, but the right approach depends on why it failed. Replacement may follow healing or stabilisation to protect surrounding bone and gum.

faqs.question: Do you have to remove a failed implant first?
faqs.answer: If an implant is loose, painful, or infected, removal might be safer before planning any replacement. We’ll outline the options and timing.

faqs.question: Will I need a bone graft?
faqs.answer: Bone support is reviewed on CBCT scans. If volume is reduced, grafting or a staged approach might be recommended to improve stability.

faqs.question: How long do I need to wait before replacement?
faqs.answer: Healing time depends on the cause of failure and bone health. Replacement isn’t always immediate; we propose a timeline after assessment.

faqs.question: Is replacement more complicated than the first implant?
faqs.answer: Revision care can involve extra planning to protect bone and soft tissue. We share a clear plan so you know the steps and rationale.

faqs.question: What are the alternatives if replacement isn’t possible?
faqs.answer: Options may include bridges, partial dentures, or staged grafting before future implants. We explain pros and considerations for each.

faqs.question: Will it hurt?
faqs.answer: Procedures are carried out with local anaesthetic and a calm pace. We also discuss comfort options tailored to your needs.

faqs.question: How much does failed implant treatment cost?
faqs.answer: Costs depend on the findings and recommended steps. We provide a transparent breakdown after assessment rather than fixed figures upfront.

sections.title: Concerned about an implant that hasn’t worked?
sections.strapline: Book a calm implant review in Shoreham-by-Sea and we’ll explain your options clearly and carefully.
